description: The public of Thailand is advised on Feb 3rd by the Ministry of Health not to believe all of the circulating rumors from different sources. Please “Check before you Share.” Do not share the news situation from unreliable sources because incorrect information may cause widespread panic. Individuals spreading fake information can be found guilty under Thailand’s Computer Crime Act of 2017

compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On Wednesday (Apr 1), the Bangkok Metropolitan Administration had mandated a closure of Bangkok’s parks and imposed a nighttime curfew on all shops, including convenience stores and supermarkets, from midnight to 5 am, effective until the end of April.

Thailand will go under a nationwide nighttime curfew from Friday (April 3), in the latest measure to stop the spread of the coronavirus. The curfew will run from 10 pm to 4 am and violators could face up to 2 years in prison and a fine of up 40,000 baht (S$1,738), according to a written order signed by Prime Minister Prayut.
Thailand's nationwide curfew was relaxed on May 17th, to apply to the hours of 11pm-4am.
Thailand is extending the state of emergency for a month until May 31, Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha announced on Tuesday (April 28). The night time curfew between 10pm and 4am will stay in place

Nonthaburi, a province bordering Bangkok, allowed retailers of mobile phones and related services to reopen on Wednesday (April 15). Udon Thani, whose 1.6 million people are a key labour source for the capital, aims to relax some restrictions as early as Saturday.
Thailand's nationwide curfew is being eased further to apply to the hours between 11pm and 3am from June 1st.
Thailand lifts nationwide curfew from June 15th
link: NA ; https://www.thejakartapost.com/seasia/2020/06/15/thailand-ends-curfew-marks-21-days-with-no-local-coronavirus-cases.html ; Jakarta Post ; Thailand ends curfew, marks 21 days with no local coronavirus cases

description: In Thailand, Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha declared a state of emergency over the coronavirus pandemic on Wednesday (March 25), unveiling tougher restrictions on normal life in Thailand. The emergency will come into effect nationwide from midnight on Wednesday and remain in force until April 30.

On 27th Mar, The Thai government elevated the level of every measure under the Emergency Decree 2005, closed some areas and control the activities in high risk areas, i.e. Bangkok Metropolitan Region, areas of tourist attractions, big cities in the region and provinces located in the southern areas including issuing measures to control going in and out of their residence.
The Royal Thai Government has decided to extend the Emergency Decree in Thailand for one more month, until 30 June, 2020, announced on May 26th

Thailand will extend its state of emergency, in place since late March, by another month to July 31, a government spokesman said on Monday (June 29). This is the third extension and comes despite there being no local cases reported in over a month and the easing of lockdown measures proceeding as planned
On July 29, Thailand's cabinet extends the country's state of emergency for a fourth time, until August 31.
link: NA ; https://asia.nikkei.com/Spotlight/Coronavirus/Thailand-extends-emergency-for-fourth-time-until-Aug.-312ikkei Asian Review ; Thailand extends emergency for fourth time until Aug. 31

description: Thailand on Wednesday, March 11th, cancelled the grant of 'Visa on Arrival' for 18 countries to contain the spread of the coronavirus. The 18 places are: Bulgaria, Bhutan, China (including Taiwan), Cyprus, Ethiopia, Fiji, Georgia, India, Kazakhstan, Malta, Mexico, Nauru, Papua New Guinea, Romania, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Uzbekistan, and Vanuatu. All arrivals from those countries have to apply for visas at a Thai embassy or consulate and travel with a medical certificate to prove they are not infected with the virus
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
The Governor of Phuket Province orders the temporary closure of all entry and exit points – land and sea – into the island, effective from 30 March, 2020, until 30 April, 2020 or further notice.

Land checkpoint: The order prohibits people and all kinds of vehicles from entering and leaving the province via the Thai Chat Chai Checkpoint. Exceptions are made for vehicles transporting food and essential items, fuel, construction materials, medical equipment, rescue operation vehicles, ambulances, vehicles for state operations, and vehicles carrying publications.

International ports: The order also prohibits people and all kinds of vessels from entering and leaving through Phuket’s international ports. Exception is made for cargo ships to unload their cargoes, but the ships and all crew are not allowed to disembark and must leave Phuket immediately after finishing their operations.

Inter-provincial waterways: People and all kinds of vessels are also banned from entering and leaving Phuket through inter-provincial waterways. Exception is made for vessels transporting food and essential items, construction materials, medical equipment, rescue boats, and medical emergency vessels

Phuket international airport remains open
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On April 8, the Royal Thai Government approved and implemented automatic visa extensions for foreign nationals whose visas expire between March 26 and April 30, 2020. Visitors from neighbouring countries who hold a temporary border pass and are stuck in Thailand following the border closures are allowed to stay in the country until the borders are re-opened

description: Thailand's public health ministry released detailed measures for travellers visiting the country on March 14th. Travellers from the Disease Infected Zones, namely China – including Hong Kong and Macau – Italy, Iran and South Korea, will be subject to a mandatory 14-day quarantine for travellers in this category. Throughout the period of quarantine, travellers must record their own symptoms in the reporting system and monitor their symptoms strictly, and there will be a surveillance officer to closely monitor travellers’ symptoms
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
Thailand's public health ministry released detailed measures for travellers visiting the country on March 14th. Travellers arriving from the countries with ongoing local transmission are required to be under observation (supervision without quarantine) in order to ensure self-monitoring for no less than 14 days until the end of the infectious period or the reason for suspicion. They must record their own symptoms in the reporting system and monitor their symptoms strictly as required by the public health ministry. The traveller must also notify the disease control officer about the places he/she visits, so that a surveillance officer can closely monitor his/her movement and contacts.

These areas include France, Spain, Switzerland, Germany, the Netherlands, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, the United Kingdom, the United States and certain cities in Japan, namely Hokkaido, Tokyo, Aichi, Wakayama, Kanagawa, Chiba, Okinawa, Kyoto and Osaka
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

The Governor of Phuket Province orders the temporary closure of all entry and exit points – land and sea – into the island, effective from 30 March, 2020, until 30 April, 2020 or further notice.
   
   Land checkpoint: The order prohibits people and all kinds of vehicles from entering and leaving the province via the Thai Chat Chai Checkpoint. Exceptions are made for vehicles transporting food and essential items, fuel, construction materials, medical equipment, rescue operation vehicles, ambulances, vehicles for state operations, and vehicles carrying publications.
   
   International ports: The order also prohibits people and all kinds of vessels from entering and leaving through Phuket’s international ports. Exception is made for cargo ships to unload their cargoes, but the ships and all crew are not allowed to disembark and must leave Phuket immediately after finishing their operations.
   
   Inter-provincial waterways: People and all kinds of vessels are also banned from entering and leaving Phuket through inter-provincial waterways. Exception is made for vessels transporting food and essential items, construction materials, medical equipment, rescue boats, and medical emergency vessels
   
   Phuket international airport remains open

description: Thailand ministry of health advised on Feb 24th that a person with an underlying disease should avoid going outbound, where there is an ongoing outbreak. If this is unavoidable, people should avoid making contact with patients who have respiratory symptoms, avoid visiting markets selling live animals and having close contact with animals, especially with sick or dead animals

The governor of Chon Buri province in Thailand, Pakkhathorn Thianchai, authorises a full lockdown of Pattaya City commencing from April 9 and set to last until April 30. Entry to the city will not be permitted for non-residents of Pattaya, while the movements of those living or working there will be restricted. Under the policy, five checkpoints will be set up on roads leading into Pattaya to strictly screen vehicles and people.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On 22nd Jan, DPM and MoPH announced that the Emergency Operations Center (EOC) has been scaled up to Level 3.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On 22 Feb, "The government has activated the national Emergency Operations Center and set up Thailand’s national emerging infectious diseases control committee that has the prime minister serving as the chairman. The committee agreed upon the integration plan of multilateral cooperation for security and to mitigate the impact caused by COVID-19"
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On 2nd Mar, the National Committee on Communicable Diseases has set the academic committee (8 people) according to the Communicable Diseases Act, B.E. 2558 on 27 December 2019. The academic committee has the responsibility and power to give advice to 1) the Minister of Public Health in the announcement of disease infected zones; 2) to provide suggestions to the Director-General on the announcement of epidemics; 3) to provide suggestions to the Minister or the Director-General on cancellation of the announcement when the disease situation is under items (1) or (2), as the case may be, has been deemed calm or when there is a valid reason; and 4) to operate as assigned by the Committee.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On 3 Feb in Thailand, the "Ministry of Public Health prepares and informs the Joint Investigation Team (JIT) and medical personnel of both government and private sectors to deal with pneumonia caused by novel coronavirus 2019 (2019-nCoV)."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On 1 Feb, the Thai government has instructed all relevant agencies to prepare to repatriate Thai nationals from Wuhan, who must undergo intense monitoring and be isolated in designated hospitals.

On 4 Feb, "Deputy Prime Minister sent medical staff to bring Thai
people back from Wuhan"
Government has entered Phase 2 of the Void-19 Outbreak
On 25th Feb in Thailand, the National committee on communicable diseases has agreed to list Covid-19 as a dangerous communicable disease (the 14th)

In Thailand, "The Deputy Prime Minister and the Health
Minister, approved and signed the MoPH announcement declaring COVID-19 as a Dangerous Infectious Disease yesterday (26 February 2020) and will announce it in the Royal Thai Government Gazette for legal enforcement on the following day."

The Ministry of Public Health determined that COVID-19 is the 14th dangerous communicable disease in Communicable Diseases Act B.E. 2558 and the effective date is 1 March 2020. In case a patient or suspected case is found, they must report to the disease control officers under the conditions and process of the MoPH, within three hours. If someone breaks the law, they shall be liable to a fine not exceeding twenty-thousand Thai baht.
type_text: Declaration of Disease under a legal act

description: On 29th Feb, COVID-19 was added as “Dangerous communicable disease” under The Royal Thai Government Gazette, and will be enforced and official by law tomorrow (1st Mar)
type_text: Government classification of COVID situation and enforcement

description: On 3 Mar, The Ministry of Public Health declared COVID-19 as a disease that must be controlled under Section 18 of the Pathogens and Animal Toxins Act, B.E. 2558. It was designated as a Group 3 disease that poses a high risk or high hazard. Any person who intends to produce, import, export, sell, transit or possess the coronavirus that causes COVID-19 must ask for permission in order to comply with the Pathogens and Animal Toxins Act, B.E.2558.
type_text: Regulations of production, import and export of goods.

description: On 4 Mar in Thailand, The Ministry of Interior and the Ministry of Public Health are to jointly integrate and link data to comply with the Public Disaster Prevention and Mitigation Act, B.E. 2550.

The economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic has led Thailand’s Ministry of Finance, with the approval of the cabinet, to implement tax and non-tax relief measures to aid the general public, workers, and entrepreneurs.  Including: reduction of witholding tax rates, increased tax deductibility for SMEs' loan interest and salary costs as well as an acceleration of the VAT refund process. Phase 1 Tax Relief Measures will beign on Mar 10 and Phase II will begin on Mar 24.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Thailand's Cabinet approved a stimulus package on Tuesday (March 10) worth an estimated US$12.7 billion (S$17.6 billion) to help alleviate the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on already-faltering domestic activity.

In Thailand, next week (from 15 Mar), the Bangkok Communicable Disease Committee will hold a meeting to implement the law under Article 35 of the Communicable Disease Act 2015 (B.E. 2558) to allow the order to close any place.
type_text: Increasing legal basis for enforcement of laws

description: On 22nd Mar, In Thailand, the National Communicable Disease Committee has advised every provincial governor to create a database of travelers returning from Bangkok and its suburbs to their hometowns, with the beginning of the data collection starting on 2 March 2020 onwards

On 31 March 2020, the Thai government issued 3 notifications extending the deadlines for filing several types of tax returns, as approved by the Cabinet on 24 March 2020, to help boost the economy during the COVID-19 outbreak.
type_text: Extension of deadlines of tax returns
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Thailand's government issued a warning Tuesday (March 31) that April Fool's Day jokes about the Covid-19 (coronavirus) are punishable by a law which carries a sentence of up to five years in prison.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description:
"Thailand's Cabinet approved a package of economic measures worth 1.9 trillion baht (S$82.5 billion) on Tuesday (April 7) to alleviate the impact of the coronavirus outbreak, Finance Minister Uttama Savanayana said.

The package for South-east Asia's second-largest economy includes a law to borrow one trillion baht plus central bank measures worth another 900 billion baht in soft loans and support for corporate bonds, Mr Uttama told a news conference.

Of the one trillion baht borrowing, 600 billion baht will be for public health works and relief measures, and the rest for rebuilding the economy and job creation, Mr Uttama said.

The government expects to start borrowing in early May, mainly from domestic sources, he said."

On 9th Apr. "Bangkok became the latest province in Thailand to temporarily ban alcohol sales in an effort to prevent social gatherings that can spread the novel coronavirus.

The restriction from April 10 to April 20 is the metropolitan region's latest effort to contain a surge in infections since early March.

Alcohol is now proscribed for about 16 million people, as several others among the nation's 77 provinces have already imposed curbs. Thailand as a whole is under a state of emergency and partial lockdown through April."
On 17th Mar,  Thailand’s traditional new year festival Songkran has been postponed

In thailand, more than 1,040,000 Village Health Volunteers and 15,000 Bangkok Health Volunteers have been an important group operating with local officials. They have checked almost 12 million houses, given them information, emphasized the social distancing measures and searched 2,266 people who are at risk to bring them into the treatment system.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 16th Apr, In accordance with the announcement by the Ministry of Finance to postpone corporate income tax submission for the 2019 accounting year (Por.Ngor.Dor.50) to 31 August 2020, Thailand's Board of Investment has extended the application deadline for corporate income tax exemption privileges to 31 July 2020, or not less than 30 days before the corporate income tax filing date.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
"Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha called on the country's 20 richest people on Friday (Apr 17) to help in addressing the damaging economic fall-out from the coronavirus epidemic.

In a televised address that swiftly drew social media scorn, Prayut did not say exactly what assistance he sought. He said he would send an open letter to the 20 magnates next week."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Thailand extended a nationwide ban on alcohol sales until April 30. A previous 10-day ban in Bangkok, coinciding with an annual national holiday, had been due to end on April 20

"Thailand's armed forces have made budget cuts and suspended artillery purchases, as millions of Thais suffering from the adverse economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak await cash handouts from the government.

The Thai army was the latest branch of the armed forces to slash its 2020 budget on Wednesday (April 22) by about 10 billion baht (S$441 million), out of the total of 18 billion baht cut by the Defence Ministry.

It also halved its planned 900 million baht procurement of over 100 Stryker armoured infantry carriers from the United States and suspended purchases of other artillery, army spokesman Winthai Suvaree told a press briefing."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Royal Government Gazette announced the territories outside the Kingdom of Thailand: the Republic of Korea, the Italian Republic, the Islamic Republic of Iran and the People’s Republic of China, including Special Administrative Regions of Macau and Hong Kong, are to be defined as Disease Infected Zones of the dangerous communicable disease for Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) in B.E. 2563 (2020).
On 21st Jan, travelers to Thailand were issued Health Beware Cards  for an advisory on nCoV,
In Thailand on 26th Jan, the public was advised not to believe all of the circulating rumors from different sources.
On 26th Jan, Thai public is advised: While travelling abroad, people should wear a mask and avoid visiting crowded places or making contact with patients who cough and sneeze.
On 26th Jan, Public is advised: Regularly wash hands with water and soap or use an alcohol gel. It is also recommended to avoid using your hands to touch your eyes, nose, and mouth.
On 31st Jan, Thailand encourages people to bring a mask when going outside of their residences, and frequently wash hands with soap and water or alcohol gel.
On 1 Feb, Thai government has advised: Avoid eating uncooked food, use serving spoons, wash your hands

On 1 Feb, Thai government has extended its advisory on masks. Public is advised:  For the process of discarding used masks, it is recommended to fold the mask into a prepared bag and cover it fully before discarding into a closed cover bin. Hand washing is also recommended after discarding. However, if anyone uses fabric masks, please provide a back up mask. Wash and dry them in the sun after every use.

On 5 Feb in Thailand, MoPH advised drivers of public transportation to clean the surfaces that passengers frequently touch, such as door handles, seat cushions and armrests, with detergent or disinfectant or 70% alcohol solutions, which can destroy the virus. Drivers should wear a face mask while driving. Drivers can use a mask made from fabric and should wash their hands frequently.
On 7 Feb in Thailand, For the general population, the Department of Mental Health (DMH) will conduct mental health surveys and will respond as well as help solving their problems

On 10th Feb in Thailand, MoPH advised that: Most often, novel coronavirus can generally spread through respiratory droplets with about a maximum of two metres distance from the infected person. People can be infected by direct contact with secretions including saliva, and phlegm that virus can transmit through mucous by touching their mouth, eyes, or nose mouth with contaminated hands.

On 16th Feb, Thailand also strengthened the COVID-19 prevention and control measures by organizing training to provide knowledge on disease prevention and control to village health volunteers. This kind of training will be beneficial for village health volunteers in disseminating and sharing the right information on how to prevent disease transmission to their family, relatives and people in their communities. People are recommended to eat cooked food, use a serving spoon, frequently wash hands, wear a mask and exercise.

on 17th Feb in Thailand, Emergency Operations Center, Department of Disease Control ordered Chief Medical Officers of Provincial Public Health Offices to campaign for the public to regularly wash hands and using cloth masks and clean surface areas that may be a source of infection, especially among the group of public transport operators and foreign tourist service providers

On 20th Feb, The Ministry of Public Health In Thailand reported that the people who traveled back from the COVID19 transmission area have some concerns. Those people who do not have a fever, cough and runny nose or symptoms that meet the criteria, they do not need to be admitted to the hospital but it is recommended that they observe their symptoms by themselves.

On 27th Feb in Thailand, "The Department of Disease Control opened  2
new channels of communication called “คร. OK” Chatbot and “รู้กันทันโรค” Line Application to provide information and recommendations including FAQ to the public. People can listen to the automated messages or leave a question or message through these kinds of channels and an officer will respond back."

In Thailand on 7 Mar, The Ministry of Public Health has increased the channels to provide education and advice for the people about COVID-19 on Twitter, Facebook, Line Official, Tik Tok, "ไทยรู้สู้โควิด" and Line Official ChatBot 1422 "Kor-Ror-OK."
Thailand's government issued a warning Tuesday (March 31) that April Fool's Day jokes about the Covid-19 (coronavirus) are punishable by a law which carries a sentence of up to five years in prison.

In Thailand on 10 Apr, the Ministry of Public Health recommended Songkran festival this year should give love, prayers blessings via online channels, to focus on social distancing and prevent the elderly from infection
On 17th Feb in Thailand,Thai cruise passengers will be screened and followed up for 14 days.
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
On 23rd Feb in Thailand, "MOPH has advised people traveling from areas with reports of ongoing outbreaks or
local transmission including the People's Republic of China (including Hong Kong Special
Administrative Region, the Macau Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China,
Republic of China (Taiwan), Japan, Singapore, the Republic of Korea (South Korea), (a list of
countries with report of outbreaks will be announced periodically for people to monitor the situation
through the DDC website), are asked to take social responsibility by self-monitoring at least 14 days
upon return, avoiding crowded places, avoiding using public transportation, and avoiding sharing
personal household items. "
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 23rd Feb in Thailand, "students, undergraduate/graduate students, and personnel traveling from areas with reported outbreaks are to stay at home for 14 days (self-quarantine at home)"
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 24th Feb in Thailand, MoPH recommended passengers returning from outbreak areas to implement a self-quarantine for 14 days to ensure the safety of themselves, their family and community.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 28th Feb in Thailand, Persons who meet the criteria for patient under investigation (PUI) showing symptoms and having risk exposure history OR who have no symptoms but have risk of infection from confirmed or suspected cases of COVID 19. This group has to be under strict isolation
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
ON 29th Feb in Thailand, MOPH asks the
cooperation from people who return from affected areas to self-quarantine themselves for a total
of 14 days.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On 3 Mar, the group of PUI that develop suspected symptoms and have a travel history to outbreak areas shall be strictly quarantined at the hospital.
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 4th Mar in Thailand, Government officers departing from affected areas shall implement self-quarantine for 14 days (the absence from work for this quarantine will not be considered official leave)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 4th Mar, the Prime Minister assigned relevant parties to prepare to bring back Thai workers from the Republic of Korea (South Korea). All of them must be quarantined, especially the Thai workers from the two high-risk cities.

On 4th Mar, the Prime Minister assigned relevant parties to prepare to bring back Thai workers from the Republic of Korea (South Korea). All of them must be quarantined, especially the Thai workers from the two high-risk cities.
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)

description: In 5th Mar in Thailand, His Excellency the Prime Minister has instructed the Ministry of Interior, Ministry of Tourism and Sports, Ministry of Defence, Office of the Bangkok Metropolitan Administration and related agencies to jointly consider the 'areas for containing diseases' for passengers who travel from disease infected areas of COVID-19. Those who travel from disease infected areas need to be placed under control of the government. Relevant operation teams will be prepared as well.
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On 22nd Mar, In Thailand, the National Communicable Disease Committee has advised every provincial governor to provide knowledge and make returning travelers from Bangkok and its suburbs understand self-quarantine and observe fever and respiratory symptoms every day. Those travelers should avoid being close to other people in their residence until the completion of 14 days from the date of arrival in their residence.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Beginning April 2nd, local authorities in Thailand require all foreigners who enter Chiang Mai province to quarantine for 14 days at their residence or in a location provided by the Department of Disease Control. Thai nationals entering Chiang Mai from surrounding provinces are also expected to self-quarantine strictly for 14 days.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Phuket Governor Phakaphong Tavipatana has given the order for all entertainment venues in Phuket, including bars, to close for 14 days. The order comes into effect Mar 18. All sports venues, cinemas and massages shops must remain closed

Phuket Governor Phakaphong Tavipatana has given the order for all entertainment venues in Phuket, including bars, to close for 14 days. The order comes into effect Mar 18. All sports venues, cinemas and massages shops must remain closed

On 19 Mar, the Thai government has now authorized the provincial governors with the approval of the Provincial Communicable Disease Committee to consider temporarily closing places that are at-risk of spreading disease, such as pubs, restaurants, entertainment venues, boxing stadiums, etc. until the situation improves.

Shopping malls, department stores, community malls

On April 20th, Thailand extended a nationwide ban on alcohol sales until April 30. A previous 10-day ban in Bangkok, coinciding with an annual national holiday, had been due to end on April 20.

description: The nationwide alcohol sales ban in Thailand due to end on Thursday (Apr 30th) has been extended until May 31, permanent secretary for the interior Chatchai Promlert said on Thursday (Apr 30th)
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description: Sales of alcoholic beverages in Thailand will be allowed again from Sunday May 3rd, but people will only be able to drink at home and not in restaurants when they reopen. Restaurants will not be allowed to serve alcohol as part of the condition for their reopening
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description: The Governor of Phuket Province has ordered temporary closure of all beaches, zoos and animal shows, and the Bang La Walking Street, effective from 28 March, 2020, until further notice as areas catering to large groups of persons and movement of persons
On 16th Mar In Thailand, The MOPH requested the collaboration from people to strictly comply with the recommendations by keeping a distance of at least 1 meter from each other
Phuket, Thailand ordered all residents to wear either surgical or cloth masks when leaving their residence, effective from today, 7 April, 2020, until further notice
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere

description: The Ministry of Public Health (MOPH) set up social-distancing guidelines in hospitals to reduce congestion and the spread of infection in outpatient departments during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Domestic flights in Thailand may resume from May 1st with some restrictions imposed by the Civil Aviation Authority. Airlines are required to sell tickets for 70% of the capacity of each plane model, taking into account social distancing. Passengers are required to wear masks at all times
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: Domestic flights in Thailand may resume from May 1st with some restrictions imposed by the Civil Aviation Authority. Airlines are required to sell tickets for 70% of the capacity of each plane model, taking into account social distancing. Passengers are required to wear masks at all times
